[[Image:Muh-hund-original-rondellliten.JPG|thumb|right|Image by Lars Vilks published in ''Nerikes Allehanda'' adjacent to the editorial]] The '''Lars Vilks Muhammad drawings controversy''' began in July 2007 with a series of [[drawing]]s by Swedish artist [[Lars Vilks]] that depicted the [[Islam]]ic prophet [[Muhammad]] as a [[roundabout dog]] (a form of [[street installation]] in Sweden). Several art galleries in Sweden declined to show the drawings, citing security concerns and fear of violence. The controversy gained international attention after the [[Örebro]]-based regional newspaper ''[[Nerikes Allehanda]]'' published one of the drawings on 18 August as part of an [[editorial]] on [[self-censorship]] and [[freedom of religion]].{{cite news |first=Lars |last=Ströman |title=Rätten att förlöjliga en religion |url=http://www.na.se/artikel.asp?intId=1209627 |publisher=[[Nerikes Allehanda]] |language=Swedish |date=2007-08-18 |accessdate=2007-08-31 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070906190721/http://www.na.se/artikel.asp?intId=1209627 |archivedate = 2007-09-06}}
English translation: {{cite news |first=Lars |last=Ströman |title=The right to ridicule a religion |url=http://www.na.se/artikel.asp?intId=1209676 |publisher=[[Nerikes Allehanda]] |date=2007-08-28 |accessdate=2007-08-31 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070830163657/http://www.na.se/artikel.asp?intId=1209676 |archivedate = 2007-08-30}} While several other leading Swedish newspapers had published the drawings already, this particular publication led to protests from Muslims in Sweden as well as official condemnations from several foreign governments including [[Iran]],{{cite news|title=Iran protests over Swedish Muhammad cartoon |url=http://www.thelocal.se/8305/20070827/ |publisher=[[Agence France-Presse]] |date=2007-08-27 |accessdate=2007-08-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070829141345/http://www.thelocal.se/8305/20070827/ |archivedate=2007-08-29 |df= }} [[Pakistan]],{{cite press release|title=PAKISTAN CONDEMNS THE PUBLICATION OF OFFENSIVE SKETCH IN SWEDEN |publisher=[[Pakistan Ministry of Foreign Affairs]] |date=2007-08-30 |url=http://www.mofa.gov.pk/Press_Releases/2007/Aug/PR_234_07.htm |accessdate=2007-08-31 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070904154021/http://www.mofa.gov.pk/Press_Releases/2007/Aug/PR_234_07.htm |archivedate=2007-09-04 |df= }} [[Afghanistan]],{{cite news |first=Sayed |last=Salahuddin |title=Indignant Afghanistan slams Prophet Mohammad sketch |url=http://in.reuters.com/article/SouthAsiaNews/idINIndia-29281220070901 |publisher=[[Reuters]] |date=2007-09-01 |accessdate=2007-09-09}} [[Egypt]],{{cite news |first=Gwladys |last=Fouché |title=Egypt wades into Swedish cartoons row |url=http://media.guardian.co.uk/presspublishing/story/0,,2161595,00.html |work=[[The Guardian]] |date=2007-09-03 |accessdate=2007-09-09}} and [[Jordan]],{{cite news |title=Jordan condemns new Swedish Mohammed cartoon |url=https://news.yahoo.com/s/afp/20070903/wl_mideast_afp/jordanswedenislam_070903124623 |publisher=[[Agence France-Presse]] |date=2007-09-03 |accessdate=2007-09-09}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} as well as by the inter-governmental [[Organisation of Islamic Cooperation|Organisation of the Islamic Conference]] (OIC).{{cite press release|title=The Secretary General strongly condemned the publishing of blasphemous caricatures of Prophet Muhammad by Swedish artist |publisher=[[Organisation of Islamic Cooperation|Organisation of the Islamic Conference]] |date=2007-08-30 |url=http://www.oic-oci.org/press/English/2007/08/caricatur.htm |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071012054243/http://oic-oci.org/press/English/2007/08/caricatur.htm |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2007-10-12 |accessdate=2007-09-09 |df= }} The controversy occurred about a year and a half after the [[Jyllands-Posten Muhammad cartoons controversy|''Jyllands-Posten'' Muhammad cartoons controversy]] in Denmark in early 2006. == Background == [[Image:Lars Vilks 20050722.jpg|thumb|right|[[Lars Vilks]]]] On 11 June 2007, Vilks was invited to participate in an art exhibition on the theme "The Dog in Art" ({{lang-sv|Hunden i konsten}}) that was to be held in the small town of [[Tällerud]] in [[Värmland]]. Vilks submitted three [[pen]] and [[ink]] [[drawing]]s on [[ISO 216|A4 paper]] depicting [[Muhammad]] as a [[roundabout dog]]. At this time, Vilks was already participating with drawings of Muhammad in another exhibition in [[Vestfossen]], Norway, on the theme "Oh, My God". Vilks, who is a known proponent of [[institutional art]], has stated that his original intention with the drawings was to "examine the [[political correctness]] within the boundaries of the art community".{{cite episode |title=Argument 6 september 2007 : Debatt om Yttrandefrihet |episodelink= |series=Argument |serieslink=Argument (television program) |credits= |network=[[Sveriges Television]] |station=[[SVT1]] |airdate=2007-09-06 |season=2 |number=1 |minutes= }} According to Vilks, the art and culture communities in Sweden repeatedly criticize the United States and [[Israel]], whereas Muslim values are rarely even questioned.{{cite news|title=Islamists push for boycott of Swedish firms |url=http://www.thelocal.se/8542/20070919/ |publisher=[[Tidningarnas Telegrambyrå]]/[[The Local]] |date=2007-09-19 |accessdate=2007-09-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071028162633/http://www.thelocal.se/8542/20070919/ |archivedate=2007-10-28 |df= }} On 20 July, the day before the opening of the exhibition in Tällerud, the organizers decided to withdraw Vilks's drawings from the exhibition due to security concerns and fear of violence from [[Islamic extremism|Islamic extremists]] (''see [[Islam and blasphemy]] and [[Islam and animals]]''). Märta Wennerström, the exhibition's organizer, said that at first she "didn't realize the gravity of the situation" and that she made the decision to remove the drawings after consulting [[Government agencies in Sweden|Swedish government agencies]] and private persons.{{cite news|title=Muhammed som rondellhund stoppas |url=http://www.nwt.se/ArticlePages/200707/20/20070720205557_NWT845/20070720205557_NWT845.dbp.asp |publisher=[[Nya Wermlands-Tidningen]] |language=Swedish |date=2007-07-20 |accessdate=2007-08-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070823022045/http://www.nwt.se/ArticlePages/200707/20/20070720205557_NWT845/20070720205557_NWT845.dbp.asp |archivedate=2007-08-23 |df= }}{{cite news |first=Bosse |last=Brink |title=Teckningar på Muhammed togs bort |url=http://www.svd.se/dynamiskt/inrikes/did_16316985.asp |publisher=[[Svenska Dagbladet]] |language=Swedish |date=2007-07-21 |accessdate=2007-08-27}} Following the first refusal to publish the drawings, Vilks submitted his drawings to the [[Gerlesborg School of Fine Art]] in [[Bohuslän]] (where he is a frequent lecturer) for a special teachers' exhibition that was going to be opened on 18 August. On 13 August, however, the school announced that they also had decided to reject the drawings due to security concerns.{{cite news |first=Johan |last=Sjöstrand |title=Stopp igen för Vilks Muhammed-bilder |url=http://www.svd.se/dynamiskt/kultur/did_16670977.asp |publisher=[[Svenska Dagbladet]] |language=Swedish |date=2007-07-13 |accessdate=2007-08-27}} This second rejection started an intense debate in the Swedish media about [[self-censorship]] and [[freedom of expression]]. On 18 August, the [[Örebro]]-based regional newspaper ''[[Nerikes Allehanda]]'' published one of Vilks's drawings in an [[editorial]] on freedom of expression. The editorial defended "Muslims' right to freedom of religion" but also said it must be permitted to "ridicule Islam's most foremost symbols — just like all other religions' symbols." On the same day, the drawings were also published in several other Swedish newspapers including ''[[Aftonbladet]]'', ''[[Dagens Nyheter]]'', ''[[Expressen]]'' and ''[[Upsala Nya Tidning]]''. == Reactions == === International reactions === On 27 August, the Swedish ''[[chargé d'affaires]]'' in [[Tehran]], Gunilla von Bahr, was summoned to the Iranian foreign ministry where she received a protest from the [[Government of Iran|Iranian government]] against the publication in ''Nerikes Allehanda''. On 28 August the [[President of Iran]], [[Mahmoud Ahmadinejad]], commented on the drawings during a press conference. He was quoted by the [[Islamic Republic News Agency]] as saying: "Religions call for friendship, equality, justice, peace and respect for divine prophets. The Zionists only pretend to believe in religion. They are telling lies. They are perpetrating oppression against the Europeans and putting at risk the prestige of Europe." {{cite news|title=President castigates Swedish daily for publishing blasphemy |url=http://www2.irna.com/en/news/view/line-17/0708280953195316.htm |publisher=[[Islamic Republic News Agency]] |date=2007-08-28 |accessdate=2007-09-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070929091659/http://www2.irna.com/en/news/view/line-17/0708280953195316.htm |archivedate=2007-09-29 |df= }}{{cite news|title=Ahmadinejad claims 'Zionists' behind Swedish cartoon |url=http://www.thelocal.se/8319/20070828/ |publisher=[[Agence France-Presse]]/[[The Local]] |date=2007-08-28 |accessdate=2007-08-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070830131140/http://www.thelocal.se/8319/20070828/ |archivedate=2007-08-30 |df= }} On 30 August, the Swedish ''chargé d'affaires'' in [[Islamabad]], Lennart Holst, was summoned to the [[Pakistani Ministry of Foreign Affairs]] to receive a similar protest from the [[Government of Pakistan|Pakistani government]].{{cite news|first=James |last=Savage |title=Muhammad cartoon: Sweden 'sorry for hurt feelings' |url=http://www.thelocal.se/8341/20070830/ |publisher=[[The Local]] |date=2007-08-30 |accessdate=2007-08-31 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070902154003/http://www.thelocal.se/8341/20070830/ |archivedate=2007-09-02 |df= }} The Pakistani Ministry of Foreign Affairs later issued a statement where it condemned the publication "in the strongest terms". On the same day the [[Organisation of Islamic Cooperation|Organisation of the Islamic Conference]] (OIC), an inter-governmental organization which represents 57 Muslim countries, issued a statement where it strongly condemned the publishing of blasphemous caricatures of Muhammad by Swedish artist Lars Vilks in the ''Nerikes Allehanda'' newspaper. The secretary-general of OIC, [[Ekmeleddin İhsanoğlu]], further called on the Swedish government to take "immediate punitive actions against the artist and the publishers of the cartoon and asked for their unqualified apology". On 31 August, supporters from Islamic parties in Pakistan burned the [[Flag of Sweden|Swedish flag]] in the city of [[Lahore]]. In [[Karachi]], others torched an effigy of the [[Swedish Prime Minister]] to protest the cartoon.{{cite news |title=Muslims Protest Swedish Newspaper's Cartoon of Prophet Muhammad |url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,295431,00.html |publisher=[[Associated Press]] |date=2007-08-31 |accessdate=2007-09-10}} On 1 September, the [[Afghanistan|Afghan]] newspaper ''[[Kabul Times]]'' published a statement by religious scholars, imams and the Afghan [[Ministry of Islamic Guidance]]. The statement said that "The sold-out enemies of Islam draw the cartoon of the respected Prophet of Islam once more. This has disturbed the Islamic world and aroused the indignation of all Muslims". The statement demanded those responsible be handed over to a court for prosecution and punishment. On 3 September, the [[Ministry of Awqaf (Egypt)|Egyptian Ministry of Religious Endowments]] condemned the publication, saying that "such an irresponsible act is not conducive to friendly ties between the Islamic world and the west". On the same day, also the [[Government of Jordan|Jordanian government]] condemned the publication. A spokesperson for the government said that "The publication of this cartoon, which seeks to attack the character of the Prophet Mohammed, is unacceptable, rejected and condemned". === Domestic reactions === On 25 August, a group of about 60 Muslims held a demonstration outside ''Nerikes Allehanda'''s office in Örebro to protest against the publication.{{cite news|first=Erik |last=Hedtjärn |title=Demonstration mot Muhammedhundar |url=http://www.dn.se/DNet/jsp/polopoly.jsp?d=1058&a=684516 |publisher=[[Dagens Nyheter]] |language=Swedish |date=2007-08-24 |accessdate=2007-08-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070826215156/http://www.dn.se/DNet/jsp/polopoly.jsp?d=1058&a=684516 |archivedate=2007-08-26 |df= }} On 31 August, [[Prime Minister of Sweden|Swedish Prime Minister]] [[Fredrik Reinfeldt]] commented on the issue and said: "I think it's important to say two things. First, we are eager to ensure that Sweden remains a country in which Muslims and Christians, people who believe in God and people who don't believe in God, can live side by side in a spirit of mutual respect [...] We are also eager to stand up for freedom of expression, which is enshrined in the [[Constitution of Sweden|constitution]] and comes naturally to us, and which ensures that we do not make political decisions about what gets published in the newspapers. I want to make sure we keep things that way."{{cite news|title=Reinfeldt speaks out about Muhammad controversy |url=http://www.thelocal.se/8350/20070831/ |publisher=[[Tidningarnas Telegrambyrå]]/[[The Local]] |date=2007-08-31 |accessdate=2007-08-31 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070902154105/http://www.thelocal.se/8350/20070831/ |archivedate=2007-09-02 |df= }} The same day, around 300 demonstrators – led by the Islamic Cultural Centre in Örebro – assembled outside the offices of ''Nerikes Allehanda'' to protest against the newspaper's publication.{{cite news|title=Demonstrators in Muhammad picture protest |url=http://www.thelocal.se/8351/20070831/ |publisher=[[Tidningarnas Telegrambyrå]]/[[The Local]] |date=2007-08-31 |accessdate=2007-08-31 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070902153815/http://www.thelocal.se/8351/20070831/ |archivedate=2007-09-02 |df= }} On 7 September, Prime Minister Fredrik Reinfeldt met with ambassadors from 22 Muslim countries to discuss the issue. Reinfeldt said that he had "explained how Swedish society works and that we don't have elected representatives making editorial decisions", adding that "this is an open country, a tolerant country".{{cite news|title=Muslim ambassadors 'made no demands' |url=http://www.thelocal.se/8424/20070907/ |publisher=[[Tidningarnas Telegrambyrå]]/[[The Local]]/[[Agence France-Presse]] |date=2007-09-07 |accessdate=2007-09-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070910191024/http://www.thelocal.se/8424/20070907/ |archivedate=2007-09-10 |df= }} Prior to the meeting, Egyptian ambassador [[Mohamed Sotouhi]] said, according to the news agency [[Tidningarnas Telegrambyrå|TT]], that he and a group of fellow ambassadors had agreed on a list of measures that Sweden needed to take and to present it to the Prime Minister. "We want to see action, not just nice words. We have to push for a change in the law", he said.{{cite news|title=Muslim ambassadors: 'Sweden needs to change its laws' |url=http://www.thelocal.se/8412/20070906/ |publisher=[[Tidningarnas Telegrambyrå]]/[[The Local]]/[[Agence France-Presse]] |date=2007-09-06 |accessdate=2007-09-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070908151322/http://www.thelocal.se/8412/20070906/ |archivedate=2007-09-08 |df= }} After the meeting however, Reinfeldt denied that any such list had been presented to him. According to the [[Syrian Arab News Agency]], a statement had been delivered from the Swedish embassy in [[Damascus]] to Syria's [[Grand Mufti]] [[Ahmad Bader Hassoun]] in which Reinfeldt "expressed his regret of the incident which has offended and upset Muslims, calling against instigating or offending other religions".{{cite news |title=Sweden Apologizes for Newspapers Offending Muslims |url=http://www.sana.org/eng/22/2007/09/05/137784.htm |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160308164039/http://sana.org/eng/22/2007/09/05/137784.htm |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2016-03-08 |publisher=[[Syrian Arab News Agency]] |date=2007-09-05 |accessdate=2007-09-12}} The Swedish government has not commented on this statement. [[Image:Muh-hund-originallit.JPG|thumb|right|200px|One of Vilks's original three drawings, depicting [[Muhammad]] as a [[roundabout dog]].]] Also on 7 September, a group of about 550 Muslims gathered outside the offices of the newspaper ''[[Upsala Nya Tidning]]'' in [[Uppsala]], to protest against the newspaper's publication of the cartoons.{{cite news|title=Muhammad cartoons spark new protest |url=http://www.thelocal.se/8428/20070907/ |publisher=[[Tidningarnas Telegrambyrå]]/[[The Local]] |date=2007-09-07 |accessdate=2007-09-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070910031849/http://www.thelocal.se/8428/20070907/ |archivedate=2007-09-10 |df= }} == Threats and attacks == Following the publication in ''Nerikes Allehanda'', the [[Swedish Police Authority|Swedish police]] raised the security level around the newspaper's headquarters and some of its employees have been forced to use bodyguards after receiving death threats. Vilks himself has also received several death threats.{{cite news|first=Erik |last=Scherlund |title=Lars Vilks hotad till livet |url=http://tv4nyheterna.se/1.163969/nyheter/2007/08/31/lars_vilks_hotad_till_livet |publisher=[[TV4Nyheterna]] |language=Swedish |date=2007-08-31 |accessdate=2007-09-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070902105232/http://tv4nyheterna.se/1.163969/nyheter/2007/08/31/lars_vilks_hotad_till_livet |archivedate=2007-09-02 |df= }} One Muslim woman in western Sweden has been arrested on charges of issuing a death threat ({{lang-sv|olaga hot}}) against Vilks in an e-mail. The woman confirmed in police interrogation that she had written the mail and said that she did not have any regrets about it.{{cite news |title=Kvinna delgiven för mordhot av Vilks |url=http://www.svd.se/dynamiskt/inrikes/did_17015499.asp?blogAbuseID=36649 |publisher=[[Tidningarnas Telegrambyrå]] |language=Swedish |date=2007-09-05 |accessdate=2007-09-12}} On 6 September, one actual roundabout dog created by Vilks and local children was set alight as an apparent threat.[http://www.thelocal.se/8420/20070907/ The Local – Sculpture by controverial [sic] artist set on fire] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071115075921/http://www.thelocal.se/8420/20070907/ |date=November 15, 2007 }} On 15 September, it was reported that the group [[Islamic State of Iraq]] had placed a bounty of at least $100,000 on the head of Lars Vilks and 50,000 dollars on [[Ulf Johansson (editor)|Ulf Johansson]], editor-in-chief of ''Nerikes Allehanda''. The statement was found in an audio file on an Islamist website and was read by a person who identified himself as [[Abu Omar al-Baghdadi]], the purported head of the Islamic State of Iraq. "We announce a reward of $100,000 to anyone who kills this infidel criminal. This reward will be raised to $150,000 if he is slaughtered like a lamb," the statement said. The statement also threatened attacks on Swedish companies unless unspecified "crusaders" issued an apology. Vilks responded to the statement by saying: "I suppose this makes my art project a bit more serious. It's also good to know how much one is worth".{{cite news |title=Al-Qaida: Bounty on Swedish cartoonist |url=https://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20070915/ap_on_re_mi_ea/al_qaida_cartoonist_1 |publisher=[[Associated Press]] |date=2007-09-15 |accessdate=2007-09-15}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}{{cite news|title=Al-Qaeda puts bounties on heads of Swedes |url=http://www.thelocal.se/8498/20070915/ |publisher=[[Agence France-Presse]]/[[The Local]] |date=2007-09-15 |accessdate=2007-09-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070918190204/http://www.thelocal.se/8498/20070915/ |archivedate=2007-09-18 |df= }}{{cite news |title=Bounty set over Prophet cartoon |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/6996553.stm|publisher=[[BBC News]] |date=2007-09-15 |accessdate=2007-09-15}} The United States-based [[SITE Institute]] has reported that websites run by militant Islamists have listed the names of over 100 Swedish companies with addresses, maps and logos. The websites called for their readers to boycott these firms and "take revenge" on Sweden for the publication of the drawings. The [[European Council for Fatwa and Research]] (ECFR) and the [[Federation of Islamic Organizations in Europe]] (FIOE) both condemned the death threats against Vilks and Johansson. ECFR also said it planned to issue a "counter [[fatwa]]" against the threats.{{cite news|title=European Muslims condemn death sentence |url=http://www.thelocal.se/8517/20070917/ |publisher=[[Tidningarnas Telegrambyrå]]/[[The Local]] |date=2007-09-17 |accessdate=2007-09-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071027165042/http://www.thelocal.se/8517/20070917/ |archivedate=2007-10-27 |df= }} The [[World Association of Newspapers]] (WAN), which represents over 18,000 newspapers around the world, issued a statement where it condemned the death threats and expressed support for ''Nerikes Allehanda'' in its right to publish the drawing.{{cite press release |title=WAN Backs Swedish Publishers in Freedom of Expression Dispute |publisher=[[World Association of Newspapers]] |date=2007-09-17 |url=http://www.wan-press.org/article15067.html |accessdate=2007-09-19}} === 9 March 2010 arrests === On 9 March 2010, seven people were arrested in the [[Republic of Ireland]] over an alleged plot to assassinate Vilks. The arrested were originally from Morocco and Yemen and had refugee status.{{cite news |first=Shawn |last=Pogatchnik|title=Irish arrest 7 over threat to kill Swedish artist |url=http://hosted.ap.org/dynamic/stories/E/EU_PROPHET_DRAWINGS?SITE=NYBUE&SECTION=HOME&TEMPLATE=DEFAULT |publisher=[[The Buffalo News]]/[[Associated Press]] |date=2010-03-09 |accessdate=2010-03-09}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}{{cite news |title=Arrests over alleged plot to kill cartoonist |url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2010/0309/waterford.html |publisher=[[Raidió Teilifís Éireann]] |date=2010-03-09 |accessdate=2010-03-09}}{{cite news |first=Sarah |last=Stack |title=Seven held in Ireland over plot to assassinate cartoonist Lars Vilks |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/seven-held-in-ireland-over-plot-to-assassinate-cartoonist-lars-vilks-1918672.html |publisher=[[The Independent]] |date=2010-03-09 |accessdate=2010-03-09}} Of the seven, three men and two women were arrested in [[Waterford (city)|Waterford]] and [[Tramore]] and another man and woman at [[Ballincollig]], near [[Cork (city)|Cork]]. [[Garda Síochána]] (the Irish police force), which conducted the arrests with support from the [[counter-terror]] [[Special Detective Unit]] and the National Support Services, said the suspects range in age from mid 20s to late 40s.{{cite press release|title=Searches in Waterford and Cork on the 9/3/10. |publisher=[[Garda Síochána]] |date=2010-03-09 |url=http://www.garda.ie/Controller.aspx?Page=5105 |accessdate=2010-03-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110616194353/http://www.garda.ie/Controller.aspx?Page=5105 |archivedate=2011-06-16 |df= }} They (Garda Síochána) also added that throughout the investigation they had been "working closely with law enforcement agencies in the United States and in a number of European countries". The same day, [[Colleen R. LaRose]] from the [[Philadelphia]], US, suburbs, had her federal indictment unsealed charging her with trying to recruit [[Islamic terrorist]]s to murder Vilks.{{cite news |title=American Colleen LaRose Called Herself Jihad Jane |url=http://abcnews.go.com/WN/TheLaw/colleen-larose-jihad-jane-indicted-charges-helping-terrorists/story?id=10055608|publisher= ''[[ABC News]]'' |date= May 9, 2010| author = Emily Friedman and Jason Ryan }} === 2010 Stockholm bombings === {{Main|2010 Stockholm bombings}} An emailed threat sent to a news agency and to the [[Swedish Security Service]] occurred made reference to this incident.[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/sweden/8196754/Suspected-suicide-bomb-in-central-Stockholm-injures-two-and-panics-shoppers.html "Suspected suicide bomb in central Stockholm injures two and panics shoppers"][https://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/dec/12/stockholm-sweden-bombs-explosions "Stockholm explosions leave one dead and two injured"] Afterwards, two bombs exploded, injuring two people and killing the would-be attacker.{{cite news |title=Explosions in Stockholm believed to be failed terrorist attack |first=Per |last=Nyberg |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2010/WORLD/europe/12/11/sweden.explosion/index.html?hpt=T1 |newspaper=[[CNN]] |date=12 December 2010 |accessdate=12 December 2010}}{{cite news|url=http://www.thelocal.se/30782/20101212/ |title=Stockholm suicide blast a terror attack: police |last=Landes |first=David |newspaper=[[The Local]] |accessdate=12 December 2010 |date=12 December 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101215180203/http://www.thelocal.se/30782/20101212 |archivedate=15 December 2010 |df= }}{{cite news |title=Stockholm blasts kill one and injure two |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-11977524 |newspaper=[[BBC]] |date=11 December 2010 |accessdate=12 December 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101212044235/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-11977524| archivedate= 12 December 2010 | deadurl= no}}{{cite news |first=Christina |last=Anderson |author2=Bursh, John F. |title=Stockholm Hit by Blasts After E-Mail Warning |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/12/12/world/europe/12sweden.html?_r=1&hp |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=11 December 2010 |accessdate=12 December 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20130621210419/http://www.nytimes.com/2010/12/12/world/europe/12sweden.html?_r=1&hp| archivedate=June 21, 2013| deadurl= no}} === 2010 Copenhagen terror plot === {{Main|2010 Copenhagen terror plot}} At the time of the December 2010 terror arrests, Lars Vilks' home page was subject to a hacker attack. According to Vilks' blog, the hacker declared the attacks would be continued with no end and that the targets are Vilks, [[Kurt Westergaard]], and [[Geert Wilders]].[http://www.vilks.net/2010/12/30/del-1138-efter-senaste-hacket/ Lars Vilks blog, Del 1138: Efter senaste hacket]{{Primary source-inline|date=February 2015}} === 2013 Al-Qaeda's most wanted === In 2013, cartoonist [[Charb|Stéphane "Charb" Charbonnier]] was added to [[Al-Qaeda]]'s most wanted list, along with Lars Vilks and three ''Jyllands-Posten'' staff members: [[Kurt Westergaard]], [[Carsten Juste]], and [[Flemming Rose]].{{cite web|url=http://www.thewire.com/global/2013/03/al-qaeda-most-wanted-list/62673/|title=Look Who's on Al Qaeda's Most-Wanted List|author=Dashiell Bennet|date=1 Mar 2013|work=The Wire}}{{cite news|url=http://time.com/3657246/paris-charlie-hebdo-shooting/|title=Paris Police Say 12 Dead After Shooting at Charlie Hebdo|author=Conal Urquhart|work=Time}}{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/france/11330505/Murdered-Charlie-Hebdo-cartoonist-was-on-al-Qaeda-wanted-list.html|title=Murdered Charlie Hebdo cartoonist was on al Qaeda wanted list|author=Victoria Ward|work=The Telegraph}} === 2015 Copenhagen shootings === {{Main|2015 Copenhagen shootings}} On 14 February 2015, [[2015 Copenhagen shootings#Krudttønden attack|shots were fired]] at a public meeting in Denmark attended by Vilks, leaving one civilian dead and three policemen wounded.https://www.reuters.com/article/2015/02/14/us-denmark-shooting-idUSKBN0LI0N720150214 The attacker fled after a brief gunfight with police and was later shot dead the next day after committing another shooting at a [[Jewish]] [[synagogue]], killing one person and injuring two policemen. {{cite news|last1=MARTIN|first1=ARTHUR|title='Our purpose is to destroy you. We will come to you with slaughter and death' Read more: http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2956592/He-went-prison-gang-member-came-wanting-wage-holy-war-Friend-says-Copenhagen-gunman-radicalised-serving-sentence-stabbing-teen.html#ixzz3n6yV0rzc|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2956592/He-went-prison-gang-member-came-wanting-wage-holy-war-Friend-says-Copenhagen-gunman-radicalised-serving-sentence-stabbing-teen.html|accessdate=29 September 2015}} == See also == {{Div col}} * [[2017 Basirhat communal violence]] * [[Charlie Hebdo shooting]] * [[Jyllands-Posten Muhammad cartoons controversy]] * [[Islam in Sweden]] * [[Depictions of Muhammad]] * [[Islam and animals]] * [[Islam and blasphemy]] {{Div col end}} == References == {{reflist|2}} == External links == *[http://www.vilks.net/wp-content/uploads/2007/07/muhammed-rondelllit.JPG Cartoon on Lars Vilks' website] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20100315195725/http://www.stockholmnews.com/more.aspx?NID=4982 "Lars Vilks Cartoon" Stockholm News; March 13, 2010] {{Depictions of Muhammad|state=autocollapse}} [[Category:Caricature]] [[Category:Islam-related controversies in Europe]] [[Category:Events relating to freedom of expression]] [[Category:2007 controversies]] [[Category:Censorship in Islam]] [[Category:Islam in Sweden]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of Muhammad]]

revision.text:
{{caution|The term genocide is contentious and its academic definition varies. This list only considers mass killings recognized as genocides ''by the legal definition'' in significant scholarship and criteria by the UN Genocide Convention}} This '''list of genocides by death toll''' includes death toll estimates of all deaths that are either directly or indirectly caused by [[genocide]]. It does not include non strictly-genocidal mass killing (variously called [[mass murder]], [[crimes against humanity]], [[politicide]], [[policide]], [[classicide]], [[war crimes]]) such as the [[Thirty Years War]] (7.5 million deaths), [[Japanese war crimes]] (3 to 14 million deaths), the [[Red Terror]] (100,000 to 1.3 million deaths), the [[Atrocities in the Congo Free State]] (1 to 15 million deaths), the [[Great Purge]] (0.6 to 1.75 million death), or the [[Great Leap Forward]] (15 to 55 million deaths). The United Nations Genocide Convention defines genocide as "acts committed with intent to destroy, in whole or in part, a national, ethnical, racial or religious group".{{cite web|format=PDF|url=https://www.un.org/ar/preventgenocide/adviser/pdf/osapg_analysis_framework.pdf|title=Analysis Framework: Legal definition of genocide|work=Office of the UN Special Adviser on the Prevention of Genocide (OSAPG)|accessdate=16 January 2017}} Various other definitions can be found in scholarly literature and national law of different countries. ==List of the genocides== {|class="sortable wikitable" style="width:100%;" |-style="background:#CCCC;" ! style="width:20%;"| Event ! style="width:22%;"| Location ! style="width:7%;"|From ! style="width:7%;"| To ! style="width:12%;"| Lowest
estimate ! styleLatdth:12%;"| Highest
estimate ! Proportion of group killed |- | [[The Holocaust]],{{refn|name=Wannsee|group=N|'''The Holocaust''', also referred to as the Shoah, was the systematic, bureaucratic, state-organized, persecution and murder of approximately 6 million Jews by the German [[Nazi Germany|Nazi]] government and its collaborators. Initially it was carried out in German-occupied Eastern Europe by paramilitary death squads ([[Einsatzgruppen]]) by shooting or, less frequently, using ad hoc built [[Gas van|gassing vans]], and later in [[extermination camp]]s by gassing.{{r|HoloList}}
By extending its definition the Holocaust may also refer to the other victims of German war crimes during the rule of [[Nazism]], such as the [[Porajmos|Romani genocide]]'s victims, [[Nazi crimes against the Polish nation|Poles]] and other [[Slavs|Slavic civilian populations]] and [[German mistreatment of Soviet prisoners of war|POWs]], victims of [[Action T4|Germany's eugenics program]], political opponents, [[Persecution of homosexuals in Nazi Germany and the Holocaust|Homosexuals]], [[Persecution of Jehovah's Witnesses in Nazi Germany|Jehovah's Witnesses]], and civil hostages and [[Resistance during World War II|resisters]] from all over Europe.}} during [[World War II]] | [[File:Flag of the German Reich (1935–1945).svg|border|23px]] [[German-occupied Europe]] | style="text-align: center;" | 1941 | style="text-align: center;" | 1945 | style="text-align: center;" | {{nts|5750000}}
Gilbert 2001, p. 245. | style="text-align: center;" | {{nts|17000000}}
Niewyk, Donald L.; Nicosia, Francis R. (2000). The Columbia Guide to the Holocaust. New York: Columbia University Press. {{ISBN|0-231-11200-9}} | {{ntsh|25}}Around 2/3 of the Jewish population of Europe killed. Highest estimate includes 2 to 3 million Soviet POW's.Berenbaum, Michael (2006). The World Must Know: The History of the Holocaust as Told in the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum (2nd ed.). Washington, DC: United States Holocaust Memorial Museum. {{ISBN|978-0-8018-8358-3}} |- |- style="vertical-align: top;" |[[Holodomor]] (Голодомор){{refn|group=N|name=NUkraina|In 2003 '''Holodomor''', the man-made famine in [[Ukraine]], was recognized by the [[United Nations]] as the result of actions and policies of the [[Government of the Soviet Union|Soviet government]] of [[Joseph Stalin]] that caused millions of deaths,{{r|ONU2003}} and in 2008 by the [[European Parliament]] as a crime against the Ukrainian people, and [[Crimes against humanity|against humanity]].{{r|EuroParliament}} Holodomor is considered a genocide in Ukraine,{{r|InfoUkes2009}}, Australia,{{cite journal|format=PDF|url=http://www.aph.gov.au/senate/work/journals/2003/jnlp_114.pdf|title=Foreign Affairs: Ukrainian Famine (No. 680)|journal=Journals of the Senate|series=114|pages=2652–53|date=30 October 2003|deadurl=y|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20041229204050/http://www.aph.gov.au/SENATE/work/journals/2003/jnlp_114.pdf|archivedate=29 December 2004}} Canada,{{cite journal|format=PDF|url=http://www.parl.gc.ca/Content/SEN/Chamber/372/Journals/PDF/072jr_2003-06-19.pdf|title=Journals of the Senate No.72, 2nd Session, 37th Parliament|pages=994–995|date=19 June 2003|accessdate=24 July 2016}} Colombia,{{cite web|url=http://helsinki.org.ua/en/index.php?id=1198597096|title=Columbia declares Holodomor an act of genocide|work=Ukrainian Helsinki Human Rights Union|date=25 December 2007|accessdate=26 March 2008|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090219095656/http://helsinki.org.ua/en/index.php?id=1198597096|archivedate=19 February 2009}} Ecuador,{{cite web|url=http://www.congreso.gov.ec/noticias/contenido.aspx?codigo_bol=5542&sitio=noticias|title=Aprueba resolución: Congreso se solidariza con pueblo Ucraniano|trans-title=Resolution passed: Congress is in solidarity with Ukrainian people|language=es|work=National Congress of Ecuador|date=30 October 2007|accessdate=31 October 2007|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071102145045/http://www.congreso.gov.ec/noticias/contenido.aspx?codigo_bol=5542&sitio=noticias|archivedate=2 November 2007}} Estonia, Georgia, Hungary, Latvia, Lithuania, Mexico, Paraguay, Peru, Poland,{{cite web|format=PDF|url=http://ww2.senat.pl/K6/dok/dr/050/a/090s.pdf|title=Sprawozdanie - Komisji Ustawodawczej oraz Komisji Spraw Zagranicznych - o projekcie uchwały w sprawie rocznicy Wielkiego Głodu na Ukrainie|trans-title=Report of the Legislative Committee and Foreign Affairs Committee - on the project resolution concerning the anniversary of the Great Famine in Ukraine|language=pl|work=Senate of the Republic of Poland|date=14 March 2006|accessdate=24 July 2016}} and Vatican City,{{cite web|url=http://www.holodomoreducation.org/news.php/news/4 |title=International Recognition of the Holodomor|publisher=Holodomoreducation.org|date=28 November 2006|accessdate=24 July 2016}} while the [[Russia|Russian Federation]] views it as part of the wider Soviet famine of 1932-33.{{r|RussianLawmakers}} Scholars are divided and their debate is inconclusive on whether the Holodomor falls under the definition of [[Genocide Convention|genocide]].{{r|ExpressNews2005}}}}

'''Marimba Ani''' (born '''Dona Richards''') is an [[anthropologist]] and [[African Studies]] scholar best known for her work ''Yurugu'', a comprehensive critique of European thought and culture, and her coining of the term "[[Maafa]]" for the [[African holocaust]].
==Life and work== Marimba Ani completed her [[Bachelor of Arts|BA degree]] at the [[University of Chicago]], and holds [[Master of Arts|MA]] and [[Ph.D.]] degrees in anthropology from the Graduate Faculty of the [[New School University]].<ref name=disaspora>{{cite web |url= http://womenoftheafricandiaspora.com/2009/01/02/a-look-at-professor-marimba-ani/ |title=Women of the African Diaspora |first= |last= |work=womenoftheafricandiaspora.com |year=2011 |accessdate=July 4, 2011}}</ref> In 1964, during [[Freedom Summer]], she served as an [[SNCC]] field secretary, and married civil-rights activist [[Robert Parris Moses]]; they divorced in 1966.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://crdl.usg.edu/export/html/usm/crmda/crdl_usm_crmda_rand0178.html |title=Welcome to the Civil Rights Digital Library |work=crdl.usg.edu |year=2011 |accessdate=July 4, 2011}}</ref><ref name=crdl>{{cite web |url= http://crdl.usg.edu/people/a/ani_marimba/?Welcome |title=Ani, Marimba |work=crdl.usg.edu |year=2011 |accessdate=July 4, 2011}}</ref> She has taught as a Professor of African Studies in the Department of Black and Puerto Rican Studies at [[Hunter College]] in New York City,<ref name=disaspora /><ref name=crdl /> and is credited with introducing the term [[Maafa]] to describe the African holocaust.<ref name="MorrisMorris2002">{{cite book|author1=Vivian Gunn Morris|author2=Curtis L. Morris|title=The Price They Paid: desegregation in an African American community|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BBspZdkWIvsC&pg=PR10|accessdate=July 4, 2011|date=July 2002|publisher=Teachers College Press|isbn=978-0-8077-4235-8|page=10}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hunter.cuny.edu/advancement/publicrelations/makesnews/issue2/mksfaculty2/mksfaculty2.html |title=mksfaculty2 |first= |last= |work=hunter.cuny.edu |year=2003 |accessdate=July 4, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20000902020530/http://www.hunter.cuny.edu/advancement/publicrelations/makesnews/issue2/mksfaculty2/mksfaculty2.html |archivedate=September 2, 2000 |df= }}</ref>
==''Yurugu''== Ani's 1994 work, ''Yurugu: An Afrikan-Centered Critique of European Cultural Thought and Behavior'', examined the influence of European culture on the formation of modern institutional frameworks, through [[colonialism]] and [[imperialism]], from an African perspective.<ref name="Bush2004" /><ref name="ConferenceAsumah2002">{{cite book|author1=New York African Studies Association. Conference|author2=Seth Nii Asumah|author3=Ibipo Johnston-Anumonwo|author4=John Karefah Marah|title=The Africana human condition and global dimensions|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Hf1w80VTeYQC&pg=PA263|accessdate=July 4, 2011|date=April 2002|publisher=Global Academic Publishing|isbn=978-1-58684-220-8|page=263}}</ref><ref name="Hawthorne2002-17-19">{{cite book|author=Susan Hawthorne|title=Wild politics: feminism, globalisation, bio/diversity|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Um-ImUBOIb4C|accessdate=July 4, 2011 |year=2002|publisher=Spinifex Press|isbn=978-1-876756-24-6|pages=17–19, 388}}</ref> Described by the author as an "intentionally aggressive polemic", the book derives its title from a [[Dogon people|Dogon]] legend of an incomplete and destructive being rejected by its creator.<ref name="Howe1999" /><ref name="Ani1994xi1">{{cite book|author=Marimba Ani|title=Yurugu: An Afrikan-Centered Critique of European Cultural Thought and Behavior|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IBxmAAAAMAAJ|accessdate=September 17, 2011|year=1994|publisher=Africa World Press|pages=xi, 1|isbn=978-0-86543-248-2}}</ref> {{external media | align = right | width = 250px | audio1 = [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wf7s2xuQ_Vw "Marimba Ani speaks"] – Yurugu and the European ''asili'' }} Examining the causes of global [[white supremacy]], Ani argued that European thought implicitly believes in its own superiority, stating: "European culture is unique in the assertion of political interest".<ref name="Bush2004">{{cite book|author=Melanie E. L. Bush|title=Breaking the Code of Good Intentions: everyday forms of whiteness|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=NNoky-bvSr0C&pg=PA28|accessdate=4 July 2011|date=July 28, 2004|publisher=Rowman & Littlefield|isbn=978-0-7425-2864-2|page=28}}</ref>
In ''Yurugu'', Ani proposed a tripartite conceptualization of culture, based on the concepts of #''Asili'', the central seed or "germinating matrix" of a culture, #''Utamawazo'', "culturally structured thought" or worldview, "the way in which the thought of members of a culture must be patterned if the ''asili'' is to be fulfilled", and #''Utamaroho'', a culture's "vital force" or "energy source", which "gives it its emotional tone and motivates the collective behavior of its members".<ref name="Hawthorne2002-17-19" /><ref name="Howe1999" /><ref name="Ani1994xxv">{{cite book|author=Ani|title=Yurugu|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IBxmAAAAMAAJ|accessdate=September 17, 2011|year=1994|publisher=|page=xxv|isbn=}}</ref>
The terms Ani uses in this framework are based on [[Swahili language|Swahili]]. ''Asili'' is a common Swahili word meaning "origin" or "essence"; ''utamawazo'' and ''utamaroho'' are neologisms created by Ani, based on the Swahili words ''utamaduni'' ("civilisation"), ''wazo'' ("thought") and ''roho'' ("spirit life").<ref name="Howe1999" /><ref name="Mazrui2004">{{cite book|author=Alamin M. Mazrui|title=English in Africa: after the Cold War|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bAYAaa2IwCcC&pg=PA101|accessdate=4 July 2011|year=2004|publisher=Multilingual Matters|isbn=978-1-85359-689-6|page=101}}</ref><ref name="Hawthorne2002">{{cite book|author=Susan Hawthorne|title=Wild politics: feminism, globalisation, bio/diversity|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Um-ImUBOIb4C&pg=PA388|accessdate=4 July 2011|year=2002|publisher=Spinifex Press|isbn=978-1-876756-24-6|page=388}}</ref> The ''utamawazo'' and ''utamaroho'' are not viewed as separate from the ''asili'', but as its manifestations, which are "born out of the ''asili'' and, in turn, affirm it."<ref name="Ani1994xxv"/>
Ani characterised the ''asili'' of European culture as dominated by the concepts of separation and control, with separation establishing dichotomies like "man" and "nature", "the European" and "the other", "thought" and "emotion" – separations that in effect end up negating the existence of "the other", who or which becomes subservient to the needs of (European) man.<ref name="Hawthorne2002-17-19" /> Control is disguised in universalism as in reality "the use of abstract 'universal' formulations in the European experience has been to control people, to impress them, and to intimidate them."<ref name="Ani199472">{{cite book|author=Ani|title=Yurugu|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IBxmAAAAMAAJ|accessdate=January 19, 2012|year=1994|publisher=|page=72|isbn=}}</ref>
According to Ani's model, the ''utamawazo'' of European culture "is structured by ideology and bio-cultural experience", and its ''utamaroho'' or vital force is domination, reflected in all European-based structures and the imposition of Western values and civilisation on peoples around the world, destroying cultures and languages in the name of progress.<ref name="Hawthorne2002-17-19" /><ref name="Higgs2000">{{cite book|author=Philip Higgs|title=African Voices in Education|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iaoOhJIZ5ZoC|accessdate=4 July 2011|year=2000|publisher=Juta and Company Ltd|isbn=978-0-7021-5199-6|page=172}}</ref>
The book also addresses the use of the term [[Maafa]], based on a Swahili word meaning "great disaster", to describe [[slavery]]. [[African-centered]] thinkers have subsequently popularized and expanded on Ani's conceptualization.<ref name="Dagbovie2010" /> Citing both the centuries-long history of slavery and more recent examples like the [[Tuskegee study]], Ani argued that Europeans and white ''Americans'' have an "enormous capacity for the perpetration of physical violence against other cultures" that had resulted in "antihuman, genocidal" treatment of blacks.<ref name="Dagbovie2010">{{cite book|author=Pero Gaglo Dagbovie|title=African American History Reconsidered|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KMum6d1bX-cC&pg=PA191|accessdate=July 4, 2011|date=15 March 2010|publisher=University of Illinois Press|isbn=978-0-252-07701-2|page=191}}</ref><ref name="Ani1994427434">{{cite book|author=Ani|title=Yurugu|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IBxmAAAAMAAJ|accessdate=September 17, 2011|year=1994|publisher=|pages=427, 434|isbn=978-0-86543-248-2}}</ref>
===Critical reception=== Philip Higgs, in ''African Voices in Education'', describes ''Yurugu'' as an "excellent delineation of the ethics of harmonious coexistence between human beings", but cites the book's "overlooking of structures of social inequality and conflict that one finds in all societies, including indigenous ones," as a weakness.<ref name="Higgs2000"/>{{rp|175}} [[Molefi Kete Asante]] describes ''Yurugu'' as an "elegant work".<ref>[[Molefi Kete Asante]], "[https://books.google.com/books?id=bsayWnizUD0C&pg=PA198 Afrocentricity, Race, and Reason]", in [[Manning Marable]], ed., ''Dispatches from the Ebony Tower: intellectuals confront the African American experience'' (New York, NY: Columbia University Press, 2000), {{ISBN|978-0-231-11477-6}}, page=198. Accessed: July 4, 2011.</ref> Stephen Howe accuses Ani of having little interest in actual Africa (beyond romance) and challenges her critique of "Eurocentric" logic, since she invests heavily in its usage in the book.<ref name="Howe1999">{{cite book|author=Stephen Howe|title=Afrocentrism: mythical pasts and imagined homes|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pFrm19cZhugC&pg=PA247|accessdate=July 4, 2011|year=1999|publisher=Verso|isbn=978-1-85984-228-7|pages=247–248}}</ref>

{{refimprove|date=September 2008}} {{Judicial interpretation}} The '''mischief rule'''<ref>http://legal-directory.net/english-law/interpretation-mischief-rule.htm</ref> is one of three rules of statutory interpretation traditionally applied by English courts.<ref>"The notion has long prevailed that three different rules or approaches may be employed in ascertaining the meaning of a statute. First, there is said to be the "purpose" approach or "mischief rule"... Then there is said to be the "literal" approach or "plain meaning" rule... Finally there is what is called the "golden rule"... Source: Elmer Driedger, ''Construction of Statutes''. Toronto: Butterworths, 1983, p. 1.</ref> The other two are the "[[plain meaning rule]]" (also known as the "literal rule") and the "[[golden rule (law)|golden rule]]".
The main aim of the rule is to determine the "mischief and defect" that the statute in question has set out to remedy, and what ruling would effectively implement this remedy. In applying the mischief rule, the court is essentially asking what part of the law did the law not cover, but was meant to be rectified by Parliament in passing the bill.
The rule was first laid out in a 16th-century ruling of the [[Exchequer of Pleas|Exchequer Court]].
==Meaning and use== ''Conway v Rimmer'' is a [[rules of construction|rule of construction]] that judges can apply in statutory interpretation in order to discover Parliament's intention. In applying the rule, the court is essentially asking what the mischief was that the previous law did not cover, which Parliament was seeking to remedy when it passed the law now being reviewed by the court.
The mischief rule is of narrower application than the [[golden rule (law)|golden rule]] or the [[plain meaning]] rule, in that it can only be used to interpret a statute and, strictly speaking, only when the statute was passed to remedy a defect in the common law.
Legislative intent is determined by examining secondary sources, such as committee reports, treatises, law review articles and corresponding statutes.
The application of this rule gives the judge more discretion than the literal and the golden rule as it allows him to effectively decide on Parliament's intent. It can be argued that this undermines Parliament's supremacy and is undemocratic as it takes law-making decisions away from the legislature.
The way in which the mischief rule can produce more sensible outcomes than those that would result if the literal rule were applied is illustrated by the ruling in ''Smith v Hughes'' [1960] 2 All E.R. 859. Under the [[Street Offences Act 1959]], it was a crime for prostitutes to "loiter or solicit in the street for the purposes of prostitution". The defendants were calling to men in the street from balconies and tapping on windows. They claimed they were not guilty as they were not in the "street". The judge applied the mischief rule to come to the conclusion that they were guilty as the intention of the act was to cover the mischief of harassment from prostitutes.
==History== The rule was first set out in ''[[Heydon's Case]]'' [1584] 76 ER 637 3 CO REP 7a<ref>http://www.bailii.org/ew/cases/EWHC/Exch/1584/J36.html</ref><ref>http://www.swarb.co.uk/lisc/LitiP12001799.php</ref> where the court ruled that there were four points to be taken into consideration when interpreting a statute:
{{quote|For the sure and true interpretation of all statutes in general (be they penal or beneficial, restrictive or enlarging of the common law), four things are to be discerned and considered:
1st. What was the common law before the making of the Act.
2nd. What was the mischief and defect for which the common law did not provide.
3rd. What remedy the Parliament hath resolved and appointed to cure the disease of the commonwealth.
And, 4th. The true reason of the remedy;
And then the office of all the Judges is to make such construction as shall suppress the mischief, and advance the remedy, and to suppress subtle inventions and evasions for continuance of the mischief, and ''pro privato commodo'', and to add force and life to the cure and remedy, according to the true intent of the makers of the Act, ''[[pro bono|pro bono publico]]''.}}
==Traditional use== In the century in which it was created, and for some time thereafter, the mischief rule was used in a legislative environment very different from the one which has prevailed in the past two centuries. As [[Elmer Driedger]] notes,
{{quote|[S]ixteenth-century common law judges ... looked upon statutes as a gloss upon the common law, even as an intrusion into their domain. Hence, statutes were viewed from the point of view of their effect upon the common law, as adding to it, subtracting from it or patching it up....
Then also, in the time of ''Heydon's Case'', the judges paid more attention to the "spirit" of the law than to the letter. Having found the mischief they proceeded to make mischief with the words of the statute. They remodelled the statute, by taking things out and putting things in, in order to fit the "mischief" and "defect" as they had found them.<ref>Elmer Driedger, ''The Construction of Statutes''. Second Edition. Toronto: Butterworths, 1983, pp. 74–75.</ref>}}
==Modern use== Modern courts continue to apply the rule in a more restricted manner, and generally with a greater regard for the integrity of the statutes which they are interpreting. Driedger puts it this way: "[T]o this day, ''Heydon's Case'' is frequently cited. The courts still look for the 'mischief' and 'remedy', but now use what they find as aids to discover the meaning of what the legislature has said rather than to change it."<ref> Elmer Driedger, ''The Construction of Statutes''. Second Edition. Toronto: Butterworths, 1983, p. 75.</ref> Driedger goes on to argue that this modern use of the mischief rule ought to be understood as one of the components of what he characterized as the "modern" method of statutory construction, rather than a stand-alone rule serving (as it formerly had), as an alternative to the methods of construction proposed by the plain meaning rule and the golden rule.
== Advantages == * In a [[common law]] jurisdiction, the existence of precedent and the knock-on effects of construing a statute prevent misuse of the rule * The Law Commission sees it as a far more satisfactory way of interpreting acts as opposed to the golden or literal rules * It usually avoids unjust or absurd results in sentencing * It is consistent with parliament sovereignty
== Disadvantages == * It is seen to be out of date as it has been in use since the 16th century, when common law was the primary source of law and parliamentary supremacy was not established * It gives too much power to the unelected judiciary which is argued to be undemocratic * In the 16th century, the judiciary would often draft acts on behalf of the king and were therefore well qualified in what mischief the act was meant to remedy. This is not often the case in modern legal systems. * The rule can make the law uncertain

'''New Fathers 4 Justice''' is a UK-based direct action [[Fathers' rights movement|fathers' rights]] group campaigning for the rights of fathers to see their children. It is a splinter group of [[Fathers 4 Justice]].
New Fathers 4 Justice has a policy of not charging its supporters a fee, as they feel that dads need as much money and resource during the trying times of separation and divorce.
==History==
New Fathers 4 Justice (NF4J) is a fathers' rights group. It was founded in September 2008 by disgruntled activists,<ref>{{cite news|title=Stanesby denies F4J protest will end|url=http://www.plymouthherald.co.uk/Stanesby-denies-F4J-protest-end/story-12695069-detail/story.html|accessdate=8 September 2008|publisher=Plymouth Herald}}</ref> who were left awaiting trial when [[Fathers 4 Justice]] was shut down by Matt O'Connor.<ref>{{cite news|title=Fathers campaign continues|url=http://www.westerndailypress.co.uk/Fathers-campaign-continues/story-12325160-detail/story.html|accessdate=16 September 2008|agency=Western Daily Press}}</ref>
The first protest was held on 19 September 2008 in [[Bristol]], at the constituency office of Labour MP and Health Minister [[Dawn Primarolo]]. The protest was motivated by Primarolo's support of the [[Human Fertilisation and Embryology Act 2008|Human Fertilisation and Embryology Act of 2008]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Embryology protesters confronted|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/bristol/7625791.stm|accessdate=19 September 2009|publisher=BBC News}}</ref>
The group and still use [[Superhero]] costumes and comic characters in their direct action protests.

In a video taken by the protesters David Cameron told the group "I really think you've made your point and you can go now. You are frightening my children and the neighbours and that's not fair. At the time Smith said “We have been protesting within the law, we haven’t been using a loud hailer and were within our rights to be there.” And “I’m not going to give up”<ref name="ITV News">{{cite web|url= http://www.itv.com/news/meridian/update/2014-12-31/protesters-evicted-for-harassing-pms-home-vow-to-continue-fight/ |title=Protesters evicted for harassing PM's home vow to continue fight |date=2014-12-31|work=[[itv>com]]|accessdate=2015-04-02}}</ref><ref name="Oxford mail">{{cite web|url=http://m.oxfordmail.co.uk/news/11694413.Campaigners_outside_David_Cameron_s_house_in_Dean_handed_harassment_order/?ref=mr |title=Campaigners outside David Cameron's house in Dean handed harassment order |date=2014-12-30|work=[[Oxford Mail]]|accessdate=2015-04-02}}</ref><ref name="Hertfordshire Mercury">{{cite web|url=http://www.hertfordshiremercury.co.uk/New-Fathers-Justice-campaigner-Bobby-Smith/story-25796892-detail/story.html |title=New Fathers 4 Justice campaigner Bobby Smith ordered to leave area around PM's home |last=Knill|first=Vicky|date=2015-01-02|work=[[Hertfordshire Mercury]]|accessdate=2015-04-02}}</ref>
*In January 2015 Protesters seeking extra rights for fathers in family courts set up camp outside a leading MP's home in Ashtead. Headed by longtime campaigner Martin Matthews, the group of four lit fires and asked passing motorists for support as they converged outside the home of MP Chris Grayling, the Secretary of State for Justice and MP for Epsom & Ewell.<ref>{{cite news|title=Fathers' rights protesters say 'honk for justice' outside MP's Ashtead home|url=http://www.getsurrey.co.uk/news/surrey-news/fathers-rights-protesters-say-honk-8557039|accessdate=31 January 2015|publisher=Get Surrey}}</ref> *In February and March 2015 Bobby Smith carried out a number of protests alone and with others aimed at [[Harriet harman]] and the Labour pink bus campaign. Starting in Stevenage at the launch of the campaign Smith first confronted Harman in Asda and then again later in the day whilst wearing a T-shirt that had “This is what a victim of feminism look’s like” written on it. Smith said “You're dividing up men and women...you're making it them versus us. Are you thinking of getting blue van?”<ref name="Daily mail">{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2948893/Labour-s-women-PINK-bus-decision-says-Harriet-Harman-says-politics-important-left-men.html |title=Barbie bus backlash: Harriet Har-person's big idea slammed by men AND women|last=Clarke|first=Natalie|date=11 February 2015|work=[[Daily mail]]|accessdate=2015-02-11}}</ref><ref name="Independent">{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/generalelection/labour-pink-bus-angry-man-heckles-harriet-harman-over-patronising-campaign-during-tour-10038933.html?origin=internalSearch |title=Labour pink bus: Angry man heckles Harriet Harman over 'patronising' campaign during tour |last=Dearden|first=Lizzie|date=2015-02-11|work=[[The Independent]]|accessdate=2015-04-02}}</ref><ref name="Buzzfeed">{{cite web|url=https://www.buzzfeed.com/emilyashton/pinkbus-problem |title=Labour Women’s Campaign Launch Overshadowed By Pink Bus|last=Ashton|first=Emily|date=2015-02-11|work=[[Buzzfeed.com]]|accessdate=2015-04-02}}</ref><ref name="Holly Watt">{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/politics/11406076/Harriet-Harmans-pink-bus-tour-kicks-off-in-Stevenage.html |title=Harriet Harman's pink bus tour kicks off in Stevenage |last=Watt|first=Holly|date=2015-02-11|work=[[The Daily Telegraph|the Telegraph]]|accessdate=2015-04-02}}</ref> [[File:New Fathers 4 Justice Confront Harriet Harman's Pink Bus.jpg|thumb|New Fathers 4 Justice Confront Harriet Harman's Pink Bus]] *Bobby Smith and Archi Ssan also confronted Miss Harman in Croydon,<ref name="Croydon Advertiser">{{cite web|url=http://www.croydonadvertiser.co.uk/Fathers-Justice-protesters-far-right-activists/story-26046625-detail/story.html |title=Fathers 4 Justice protestors and far-right activists gatecrash Labour's 'pink bus' visit to New Addington |date=2015-02-18|work=[[Croydon Advertiser]]|accessdate=2015-04-02}}</ref><ref name="Chris baynes">{{cite web|url=http://m.yourlocalguardian.co.uk/news/11811471.Croydon_needs_a_female_MP__says_shadow_minister_on__patronising__pink_bus_tour |title=Croydon needs a female MP, says shadow minister on 'patronising' pink bus tour |last=Baynes|first=Chris|date=2015-02-23|work=[[Croydon Guardian]]|accessdate=2015-04-02}}</ref><ref name="London live">{{cite |last=Cunningham|first=Eleanor|date=2015-02-18|work=[[London Live]]|accessdate=2015-04-02}}</ref> Cambridge<ref name="ITV News">{{cite Harman’s pink bus tour |date=2015-03-12|work=[[Gloucestershire Echo]]|accessdate=2015-04-02}}</ref>
*In March 2015 after asking [[Ed Miliband]] a question at a Q and A session in Rotherhithe Smith along with other protesters were involved in an altercation outside. It was originally alleged that Mr Miliband was "punched and shoved".<ref name="Russell Myers">{{cite web|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/uk-news/ed-miliband-punched-shoved-protesters-5409428 |title=Ed Miliband punched and shoved by protesters as he walks to car |last=Myers|first=Russell|date=2015-03-27|work=[[Daily Mirror|The Mirror]]|accessdate=2015-04-02}}</ref> New Fathers for Justice later released a video showing Mr Miliband getting in the car unimpeded and smiling throughout.<ref name="Emily Ashton">{{cite web|url=https://www.buzzfeed.com/emilyashton/watch-ed-miliband-being-ambushed-by-protesters-just-hours-be |title=Watch Ed Miliband Being Ambushed By Protesters Just Hours Before TV Debate |last=Ashton|first=Emily|date=2015-03-30|work=[[Buzzfeed]]|accessdate=2015-04-02}}</ref> *In January 2016, while Bobby Smith was appearing at the magistrates' court in [[Stevenage]], three activists climbed onto the roof of the court building to support him.<ref>{{cite news |title=New Fathers 4 Justice activists dressed as Father Christmas protest on roof of Stevenage Magistrates’ Court |url=http://www.thecomet.net/news/new_fathers_4_justice_activists_dressed_as_father_christmas_protest_on_roof_of_stevenage_magistrates_court_1_4369771 |first=JP |last=Asher |work=The Comet |location=Stevenage |publisher=Archant |date=6 January 2016 |accessdate=14 January 2016}}</ref> The three were arrested and charged with aggravated trespass.<ref name=mcevoy130116/> Smith was found guilty of breaching a restraining order by putting photographs of his daughters on Facebook, and found not guilty of two charges of violating a non-molestation order.<ref name=mcevoy130116>{{cite news |title=Protests promised after three charged over fathers’ rights demonstration on roof of Stevenage Magistrates’ Court |url=http://www.thecomet.net/news/protests_promised_after_three_charged_over_fathers_rights_demonstration_on_roof_of_stevenage_magistrates_court_1_4378002 |first=Louise |last=McEvoy |work=The Comet |location=Stevenage |publisher=Archant |date=13 January 2016 |accessdate=14 January 2016}};</ref> *On the 5th August 2016, two activists (Bobby Smith, 34, and Martin Mathews, 49) staged a protest on the roof of Labour leader Jeremy Corbyns Islington home.

{{for|the basketball penalties|Offensive fouls}} {{Infobox play | name = Offensive Fouls | image = | image_size = | image_alt = | caption = | writer = Jason Long | chorus = | characters = Joey
Christine | mute = | setting = [[Canada]] | premiere = 1999 | place = | orig_lang = English | series = | subject = [[Basketball]]
[[Racism]] | genre = | web = }} '''''Offensive Fouls''''' is a [[List of Canadian plays|Canadian play]] about [[racism]] written for [[young adult fiction|young adults]], for use in [[secondary schools]].{{Cite journal|journal=Gig City|title=Theatre: Fiction stranger than truth in Offensive Fouls|author=Mike Ross|date=November 22, 2011|url=http://www.gigcity.ca/2011/11/22/theatre-fiction-stranger-than-truth-in-offensive-fouls/|accessdate=August 20, 2012}} It was written by Jason Long.{{Cite journal|journal=NiagaraThisWeek.com|title=Ten theatre companies presenting works at Courthouse Theatre|date=October 3, 2010|url=http://www.niagarathisweek.com/what's%20on/article/881858--downtown-arts-mecca|accessdate=August 20, 2012}} == History and plot == The play [[premiere]]d in 1999 and was initially produced by All Nations Theatre, the organization that commissioned Long to write the play.{{Cite journal|journal=[[Uptown (newspaper)|Uptown]]|title=Keeping it real: Offensive Fouls takes an honest look at racism, as seen through the lens of teenage love|author=Jared Story|date=February 16, 2012|url=http://www.uptownmag.com/arts/theatre/Keeping-it-real-139390553.html|accessdate=August 20, 2012}} Hustle n' Bustle Theatre made its debut with the play in 2011.{{Cite journal|journal=[[Now (newspaper)|Now]]|title=Fouls flies: The birth of Hustle n’ Bustle Theatre, Scrabble With The Stars, and more|author=Jon Kaplan|author2=Glenn Sumi|date=March 31 – April 7, 2011|volume=30|issue=31|url=http://www.nowtoronto.com/stage/story.cfm?content=179920|accessdate=August 20, 2012}} There are only two characters in the play:{{Cite journal|journal=[[Winnipeg Free Press]]|title=Racially charged play sure to score with teen audience|author=Alison Mayes|date=February 17, 2012|url=http://www.winnipegfreepress.com/arts-and-life/entertainment/arts/racially-charged-play-sure-to-score-with-teen-audience-139501463.html?device=mobile|accessdate=August 20, 2012}} Joey, a 17-year-old [[Irish Canadian|Irish-Canadian]] [[basketball]] player;{{Cite web|title=Offensive Fouls|publisher=Concrete Theatre|url=http://www.concretetheatre.ca/OffensiveFouls2012.html|accessdate=August 20, 2012}} and Christine, his [[Chinese Canadian|Chinese-Canadian]] girlfriend.{{Cite web|title=Offensive Fouls|publisher=Theatre Direct|url=http://www.theatredirect.ca/index.php/company/archives/offensive-fouls/|accessdate=August 20, 2012}} The plot follows Joey as he is benched from his basketball team after Christine suspects that he was involved in a racially motivated corner-store vandalism incident.{{Cite web|title=Young Company Touring Show|publisher=[[Neptune Theatre (Halifax)|Neptune Theatre]]|url=http://www.neptunetheatre.com/default.asp?mn=1.23.148|accessdate=August 20, 2012}} ''Offensive Fouls'' is intended for an [[Adolescence|adolescent]] audience.{{Cite web|title=Manitoba Theatre for Young People: Offensive Fouls, February 13–18|publisher=Winnipeg Arts Council|url=http://www.winnipegarts.ca/index.php?/wac/article/6326/|accessdate=August 20, 2012}} == Reception == The play was written for performances in secondary schools, and has been performed throughout [[Alberta]].{{cite book|last1=Brennan|first1=edited by Kit|title=Things that go bump|date=2009|publisher=Signature Editions|location=Winnipeg|isbn=9781897109366}} Performances have also been held in [[Niagara Falls, Ontario]], and [[Neptune Theatre (Halifax)|Neptune Theatre]] in [[Halifax, Nova Scotia]], as well as in [[Winnipeg]]. It was performed in [[Edmonton, Alberta]] as recently as 2011. The dialogue has been praised for presenting "teenagers who really sound like teenagers.” The play was nominated for a [[Dora Mavor Moore Award]].{{Cite web|title=Offensive Fouls|publisher=[[Manitoba Theatre for Young People]]|url=http://www.mtyp.ca/offensive-fouls.cfm|accessdate=August 20, 2012}} One reviewer remarked, "It’s not often the public gets a chance to see “[[Curriculum|what they’re teaching the kids these days]],” so when you do, it behooves us to pay attention because the target audience will be calling the shots before too long." ''Offensive Fouls'' was published in a collection of Canadian plays for young adults titled ''Things That Go Bump'' in 2009. ==References== {{reflist}} {{Portal |Children's literature}} [[Category:1999 plays]] [[Category:Anti-racism in Canada]] [[Category:Basketball in Canada]] [[Category:Basketball media]] [[Category:Canadian plays]] [[Category:Crime drama]] [[Category:Plays about race and ethnicity]] [[Category:Plays set in Canada]] [[Category:Works about racism]]

{{IPA notice}} '''''Orihon''''' ([[Japanese language|Japanese]]: 折本, [[Hepburn Romanization| Hepburn]]: Orihon, {{IPA-ja|oɾihoɴ}}) is a book style originating from the Tang dynasty (A.D. 618-908) in China and was later developed in the Heian period (A.D. 794-1185) in Japan.<ref>Binding Beauty: Conserving a Collection of Japanese Printed Books Barbara Korbel and Janice Katz Art Institute of Chicago Museum Studies Vol. 31, No. 2, Conservation at the Art Institute of Chicago (2005), pp. 16-23+105</ref>
== History == [[File:Livre-eventail-Japon.jpg|320px|right|Livre-eventail-Japon]]The development of orihon began in China but later took on an association with [[Japanese books]], as shown by its current name. "The development of alternatives to the roll in China is difficult to date, but it appears that at some time during the Tang period long rolls consisting of sheets of paper pasted together began to be folded alternately one way and the other to produce an effect like a [[concertina]]. It has been supposed that this form was suggested by the palm-leaf books which transmitted Buddhist texts from India to China. However that may be, it is in any case a fact that the concertina form was primarily used in China, and subsequently in Japan, for Buddhist texts. Books of this format are called orihon 折本 in Japan, and the format survived until the nineteenth century and beyond for printed Buddhist sūtras and occasionally for other books, such as reference lists, calendars, and folding maps."<ref>The Book in Japan: A Cultural History from the Beginnings to the Nineteenth Century by Peter Kornicki, p. 43. Retrieved from http://www.printsofjapan.com/Index_Glossary_O_thru_Ri.htm</ref> Laura C. Liberman notes in an article that the accordion book style used in Tibet traces back to orihon origins.<ref><Lieberman, Laura C. "The Robert C. Williams American Museum of Papermaking." JAB: The Journal of Artist's Books 15 (2001): 12-13. ProQuest. Web. 11 Mar. 2015.</ref>
=== Etymology === The combination of characters are borrowed from Chinese, which originally translates the phrase to "a loss" or "a loss of money." <ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.purpleculture.net/dictionary_details/?word=折本|title = Chinese Word - 折本|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> However, when looking at the individual characters, a different meaning is found. The Traditional Chinese characters are defined as 折 meaning "to break (e.g. stick or bone); a loss"<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.purpleculture.net/dictionary-details/?word=折|title = Meaning of 折|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> and 本 meaning "roots or stems of plants; origin; source; this; the current; root; foundation; basis; classifier for books, periodicals, files etc originally,"<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.purpleculture.net/dictionary-details/?word=本|title = Meaning of 本|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> In this context, it means a breakdown of a book. In Japanese, it combines the roots "ori" (fold) and "hon" (book).<ref>http://www.wordsense.eu/本/</ref> Edith Diehl describes orihon as a general Asian style and translates it to "stabbed binding."<ref>Diehl, Edith. "Primative Records and Ancient Book Forms." Bookbinding; Its Background and Technique. New York: Rinehart &, 1946. 12. Print.</ref>
=== Uses === Cyril James Humphries Davenport notes in his 1898 lecture that "writing upon a roll was found to be the most convenient at a very early date by the Chinese, Japanese and [K]oreans, they were also the first to find out that if the rolls were simply folded backwards and forwards between the "pages" of writing or printing, the whole book became easier to read, and this form, known as "Orihon," is used in those countries to the present day."<ref>Davenport, Cyril. "Lecture 1." Cantor Lectures on Decorative Bookbinding. London: Printed by William Trounce, 10, Gough Square, Fleet Street, E.C., 1898. 2. Print.</ref>
Traditional orihon books are associated with Japanese Buddhist works and [[e-hon]], or picture books. Modern applications are found in artistic modes, such as Tom Burtonwood's 2013 plastic rendering using a 3-D printer.<ref>http://tomburtonwood.com/portfolio-item/orihon-3d-printed-book/</ref>
== Construction == <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Orihon-crop.png|framed|right|Utagawa Hiroshige (Japanese, 1797-1858) ''Sakkyo Kageboshi Zukushi'' (Collection of Improvised Silhouette Plays) n.d.]] -->Orihon consist of a long strip of paper that is written on one side and then compacted by folding in zig-zag fashion. The orihon format is considered a step between a [[scroll]] and a [[codex]].
The style of folding is similar to that of the air bellows of a [[concertina]] or [[accordion]], such that every written page faces another written page when the book is closed. It may therefore be opened to any page.<ref>https://art2551.files.wordpress.com/2011/10/book_demo.pdf</ref> It may have a cover attached to the front and back end sections of the book. Diehl describes orihon as having stabbed holes in the back cover to allow the book to be "laced."<ref>Diehl, Edith. "Primative Records and Ancient Book Forms." Bookbinding; Its Background and Technique. New York: Rinehart &, 1946. 12. Print.</ref>
==See also == *[[Folded leaflet#Concertina fold]]
== List of Orihon works == The Museum of Metropolitan Art in New York, New York hosts a collection of orihon art. Some of that work is available to view on [http://www.metmuseum.org/collection/the-collection-online/search?ft=orihon their website.] <ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.metmuseum.org/collection/the-collection-online/search?ft=orihon|title = Metropolitan Museum of Art Orihon Collection|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> * Utagawa Hiroshige (Japanese, 1797-1858) ''Sakkyo Kageboshi Zukushi'' (Collection of Improvised Silhouette Plays) n.d. * ''Onna Kasen'', an 18th-century book written about famous Japanese female poets.<ref>http://www.raco.cat/index.php/Datatextil/article/viewFile/274608/362870</ref> * 中山聘使畧 (''Chūzan heishi ryaku'' or ''Short account of the Ryūkyūan mission'') This book explains the history and geography of Ryūkyū.<ref>http://okinawa-repo.lib.u-ryukyu.ac.jp:8080/handle/okinawa/12729</ref> * Suzuki Harunobu (ca. 1724-70).'' A beauty watching a couple drinking sake, from The Spell of Amorous Love (Enshoku koi no urakata). ''Japan, circa 1766-70. Woodblock printed chuban orihon (folded illustrated book). 7.5 x 5.125 inches (19.2 x 13 cm). This piece is part of Asia Week New York's 2015 "gallery roster" for the "celebration for Asian Art" and is provided by Scholten Japanese Art from the United States as part of their exhibition ''Erotic Art of Japan: Everybody’s Doing It.''<ref>https://alaintruong2014.wordpress.com/tag/china-tibet/</ref>
